transcript:
For my final project, I built an interactive AI-powered investment memo generator using n8n and OpenAI.
The goal was to solve a real finance problem: analysts and founders spend hours writing first-draft investment memos, even though most of the structure is repetitive.
My tool automates that first draft so users can focus on judgment, not formatting.
The problem I'm solving is that early-stage analysts, bankers, and founders need fast, clear investment memos, but writing them from scratch is time-consuming and inconsistent.
This is especially painful when you're screening multiple deals or startups.
I built something I would personally use in finance roles — a tool that turns raw inputs into a professional memo instantly.
I used n8n as the workflow engine and OpenAI's language model as the reasoning layer.
The workflow has three core parts:
A webhook that accepts user input
An OpenAI node that generates the memo
A response node that sends the result back to the user
Everything is live and interactive — no hardcoded text, no fake outputs.
Let me walk through the actual code logic.
First, the Webhook node creates an endpoint called /investment-memo.
This allows anyone to send a POST request with basic financial inputs like company name, industry, revenue, growth rate, margins, valuation, and risks.
Next, that data flows directly into the OpenAI node.
In the system message, I define the role of the AI as a professional investment analyst.
In the user message, I dynamically inject the webhook inputs using n8n expressions — so the AI is reasoning over real user-provided data, not placeholders.
I also explicitly tell the model what to produce:
a business overview, an investment thesis, key risks, and a recommendation.
This mirrors how real investment memos are structured in banking and private equity.
Finally, the Respond to Webhook node returns the AI's output as a clean text response.
That means the tool works instantly in Postman, a browser, or a front-end app."To test it, I sent multiple real scenarios through the webhook — SaaS companies, different growth rates, different risk profiles — and the memos adjusted correctly each time.
The responses were coherent, structured, and usable as real first drafts.
This can easily scale.
I could add PDF uploads, financial statement parsing, valuation sensitivity analysis, or even export directly to Word or PDF.
Because it's built in n8n, I can also connect it to databases, CRMs, or deal pipelines."The biggest thing I learned is that building with AI isn't about prompting — it's about systems.
The hard part wasn't the model; it was wiring inputs, handling failures, and making something that actually works end-to-end.
This project taught me how AI fits into real financial workflows, not just theory."This isn't a demo or a mockup — it's a working product.Someone could use this today, and that was the goal."
